issues.details: Opposes expanding conscription to women citing cost, labor shortage, and added burden on women already shouldering unpaid domestic work.
Advocates for extending conscription to women as a step toward true gender equality and stronger national defense.
Recent survey shows 64% of respondents oppose the expansion of conscription to women.

responses.clarification: The government maintains that adding women to compulsory service would strain labor markets, increase costs, and impose unfair burdens on women already engaged in unpaid domestic labor.
Rothen clarifies that the initiative seeks genuine equality, arguing that all young people should contribute to community welfare through military, civil defense, or volunteer service.

evaluations.opinion: The article presents the Swiss governmentâ€™s opposition as grounded in practical concerns, while portraying the initiative as a progressive move toward gender equality.

confirmed_facts: A Swiss referendum on 30 November 2025 is held to decide whether to extend compulsory service to women.
Approximately 35,000 men currently serve in compulsory military or civil defense roles each year.
A GFS Bern survey reports 64% opposition to the expansion.
The Swiss government publicly opposes the expansion citing cost and labor market concerns.
unconfirmed_allegations: The expansion will significantly strengthen Switzerlandâ€™s national security.
Women will face disproportionately high burdens from compulsory service.

timeline.event: Swiss referendum held to decide on extending conscription to women.
Swiss government issues opposition statement citing cost and labor concerns.
Noemi Rothen releases statement supporting the initiative as a step toward equality.
GFS Bern publishes survey showing 64% opposition.
AP and AFP report on the referendum and public debate.
